Gabe Walker.Action: Bends down to light Hal's match in the cold wind, showing familiarity and a shared routine.
Responds to Hal's sarcastic comment with a teasing question, indicating friendly rapport.
Fearlessly, swiftly scaling the tower without safety lines, as if he's done it a hundred times.
Finds a fingertip-width handhold at arm's length and pulls himself up with a tough move.
Slumps down next to the couple and tries to light a cigarette but the lighter only sparks.
Bends down to take the match from Hal, showing familiarity and calm in the situation.
Carefully anchors the lifeline, extinguishes and pockets cigarette butt, gives safety instructions to Hal, helps rig harness.
Jokes with Susan about Hal showing her a good time.
Communicates clearly and effectively over the radio to coordinate the rescue operation.
Successfully grabs the rescue wire despite it being just out of reach and secures it to a heavy piton, anchoring the lifeline across the chasm.
Extinguishes his cigarette in the snow and pockets the butt, showing attention to detail and responsibility.
Gives clear safety instructions to Hal before the crossing.
Gives Susan a reassuring smile, meticulously checks her harness, and gently encourages her to cross the line despite her fear.
Turns Susan's head gently to face him and reassures her with calm, supportive words.
Meticulously re-checks Susan's harness and rigs her carefully before the crossing.
Gives Susan a reassuring smile and calm encouragement to overcome her fear.
Gently corrects Susan's panicked behavior by turning her head to face him and instructing her to focus on him, not the drop.
Encourages Susan with 'OK' signals and reassurances while she crosses.
Responds immediately and calmly to Susan's fall by moving to rescue her, maintaining eye contact and urging her to keep looking at him.
Maintains control and calmly reassures Susan while preparing to rescue her.
Clips himself with a safety line and moves smoothly and quickly along the line to reach Susan.
Urgently accelerates his movement to counteract Susan losing her grip, showing situational awareness and adaptability.
Urgently pulls himself along the line to reach Susan, locking eyes with her to keep her focused and calm.
Deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himself at Susan to try to catch her as she falls.
Twists helplessly on the safety line, unable to do more as Susan falls to her death, showing his emotional turmoil and helplessness.
Pulls himself quickly and smoothly along the line toward Susan, trying not to shake the line and maintaining eye contact to help her focus.
Recognizes the harness is failing and accelerates his approach to Susan.
Deliberately lets go of the main line and launches himself at Susan to try to catch her.
Fails to catch Susan as their hands miss, leaving him helplessly suspended on the safety line.
Twists and spins helplessly on the safety line, unable to do anything further as Susan falls.
Keeps eye contact with Susan to help her focus despite the danger.
Deliberately lets go of the main line to try to save Susan, risking himself.
Sweating, panting, visibly shaken a year after Susan's fall, showing emotional vulnerability.
Responds flatly and briefly to rental agent, showing detachment.
Happy to see Maggie but also uneasy, indicating complex feelings but not rejecting her.
Fiddles with equipment and attempts small talk with Maggie, showing willingness to engage.
Avoids saying goodbye to Maggie to escape hearing repeated blame about the accident.
Questions Maggie if she truly believes it wasn't their fault, showing vulnerability and desire for reassurance.
Expresses deep guilt and sorrow over Susan Collins' death, indicating sincerity and emotional openness.
Engages in a tense conversation acknowledging the equipment failure was a rare accident and not due to negligence.
Expresses doubt and emotional struggle over the accident and his role in it, showing internal conflict but also self-awareness.
Does not deny responsibility but questions the reassurance given, indicating a thoughtful and reflective mindset rather than denial or blame-shifting.
Engages in a hostile confrontation with Hal, nearly fighting him and escalating tensions.
Responds to Frank's attempt to defuse the situation by agreeing to meet new guys, showing some social openness.
Challenges Hal to a physical confrontation and shows aggressive confidence.
Proposes to show rookies how to death-rig a woman properly, indicating skill and willingness to teach.
Accepts Hal's order to take the Bronco and leave without further argument, showing practical compliance.
Checks the plane thoroughly an hour ago to ensure security.
Confidently explains the security measures including electronic tracers and guards.
Dismisses concerns about an inside job based on his inspection and knowledge.
Visits Susan Collins' grave on the anniversary of her death, lays down flowers, and pauses in quiet remembrance.
Brushes snow off Susan Collins' grave, lays down flowers, pauses thoughtfully, then drives away reflecting on his connection to the countryside.
No direct action or statement by Gabe Walker in this excerpt; focus is on Travers and others.
Thought of a detailed plan involving fake bodies and money to cover up the operation, showing foresight and preparation.
Relies on others (Travers) to execute the risky midair operation and does not appear directly involved in piloting or managing the planes.
No direct action or involvement in this excerpt; others (Travers, Qualen) are handling the situation.
No direct action or involvement shown in this excerpt; others handle the crisis while Gabe is absent or unmentioned.
Enters his former home with care and nostalgia, smiles at old photos showing happy memories with loved ones.
Closes the back door that was left open, showing respect for the property and concern for safety.
Approaches the shed calmly and with interest, indicating attentiveness and concern for what might be inside.
Pulls into driveway but hesitates before cutting engine, showing caution and situational awareness.
Enters unlocked cabin and surveys surroundings carefully, recognizing personal items and assessing environment.
Responds to back door swinging open by promptly closing it and investigating tracks leading to shed.
Asks Maggie to introduce him to the injured eagle, shows concern about the eagle's injury and poachers, offers to help with the dressing despite awkwardness.
Acknowledges the eagle's fight and resilience, expresses sympathy for the animal's suffering.
Appears awkward and hesitant when entering the shed and meeting Maggie, but still engages sincerely.
Recognizes the eagle's injury and age, correctly estimates about four months old and first flight timing.
Offers to assist with changing the dressing and quickly adapts to the situation by suggesting Maggie hold the eagle while he does the dressing.
Shows awareness of the eagle's nervousness and adjusts behavior to calm it.
Appears awkward and unsure when first entering the shed, hesitating to introduce himself.
Carefully tapes a small patch on the eagle's side, showing care for the injured animal.
Tentatively reaches for Maggie's face, indicating a desire for closeness and affection.
Expresses sincere feelings to Maggie, admitting he came back for her and still cares deeply.
Invites Maggie to start over somewhere else, showing hope and willingness to build a future together.
Responds angrily to Hal's sudden appearance, showing frustration but quickly engages to help.
Carefully tapes a small patch on the eagle's side, showing attention to detail and care.
Tentatively reaches for Maggie's face but respects her boundary when she pushes his hand away.
Openly admits emotional vulnerability and confusion about his feelings and situation.
Decides not to stay but wants Maggie to come with him to start over, showing decisiveness and a plan.
Responds angrily and abruptly to Hal's sudden request for help.
Refuses to help with the rescue, citing past trauma and conscience, and tells Hal to handle it alone.
Acknowledges Hal's point about responsibility and hesitates, showing internal conflict and fear.
Soloed a difficult climb that others can't do, demonstrating past skill and capability.
Refuses to participate in a rescue mission despite the urgency and need, citing personal conscience issues and fear.
Hesitates and shows fear when confronted with responsibility, indicating lack of confidence in current situation.
Acknowledges Hal's point and slows down, showing some internal conflict and potential reconsideration.
Acknowledges Maggie silently by nodding, showing awareness of others' presence and feelings.
Offers Hal a backup tool despite Hal's skepticism, indicating consideration and support.
Makes a lighthearted bet with Hal about the climb, showing friendly and sincere interaction.
Takes the lead on the climb, prepares rope and bolt gun, relies on previous experience by recalling where bolts were placed.
Uses the bolt gun as a backup despite Hal's comment that it is useless for ice climbing, showing practical judgment.
Engages in light banter with Hal about free climbing and the bet, maintaining confidence and composure.
Leads the climb by placing pitons and anchoring the rope to ensure safety for both himself and Hal.
Leads the climb by planting pitons into the ice and anchoring the rope securely, demonstrating careful and skillful climbing technique.
Shouts warnings to Hal during the rockslide, tries to protect him by quickly removing the carabiner clip to arrest the fall.
Anchors the rope securely in the ice with a piton before Hal climbs up.
Hugs the ice wall and shouts a warning during the rockslide, showing situational awareness and quick reaction.
Quickly removes the carabiner clip from his anchor to prevent the entire rope system from failing as Hal falls.
Warns Hal loudly about the rockslide, showing concern for his safety.
Quickly acts to secure the rope by firing a bolt into solid rock to save Hal from falling.
Takes most of the physical impact himself to protect Hal, enduring pain silently.
Shares a moment of giddy, relieved laughter with Hal after the near-death experience, reconnecting their friendship.
Quickly reacts to the rockslide by hugging the ice wall and shouting a warning to Hal.
Removes the carabiner clip from the piton to prevent further failure as Hal falls.
Uses the bolt gun to fire a new anchor into solid rock rapidly under pressure.
Braces himself effectively for the jolt of Hal's fall, taking the impact on his shoulders despite the ice ledge breaking.
Maintains composure enough to confirm the anchor is secure and communicates this to Hal.
Shares a moment of laughter with Hal after the near-death experience, showing emotional resilience and camaraderie.
Helps Hal up as they near the mountain's edge, encouraging him by saying 'Come on -- the hard part's over.'
Shows wariness and caution by carefully looking around the plane wreckage instead of rushing in.
Expresses concern and suspicion about the situation, indicating attentiveness and sincerity.
Encourages Hal by saying 'Come on -- the hard part's over' despite being tired, showing leadership and confidence.
Helps Hal up at the mountain's edge, demonstrating physical capability and teamwork.
Observes the fuselage carefully and questions the situation ('Something's wrong here --'), showing critical thinking and situational awareness.
Does not rush into the fuselage but takes a wary look around, indicating caution and good judgment.
Notes footprints and inspects the cable carefully, showing attentiveness and concern for the situation.
Responds to Travers' comment about Maggie by simply stating 'My ex' without bitterness or hostility.
Does not resist or escalate the situation when confronted and disarmed by Qualen and others, showing restraint and cooperation.
Notes fresh footprints and inspects the cable wrapped around the tree, recognizing it as no ordinary accident.
Gets caught off guard by Qualen's gun barrel behind him and is quickly disarmed and hustled inside the plane.
Nods to accept leading the expedition despite being coerced at gunpoint.
Leads the group up a difficult climb, choosing a route accessible to novices, showing consideration for others' abilities.
Pauses too long and hesitates when pressured, then complies under threat.
Quietly tells Hal they don't have to continue, indicating concern and possible reluctance to endanger others.
Leads the expedition down a steep but passable descent and up a challenging mountain wall using natural ledges and climbing gear, guiding others safely.
Pauses too long when assessing the first blip on the monitor, requiring a nudge from Qualen to proceed.
Expresses concern about Maggie's safety, acknowledging the danger beyond just the immediate threat.
Complies with Travers' demands (fetching equipment) despite the tense situation, showing cooperation.
Suggests a plan to get ahead of pursuers despite risks, showing strategic thinking.
Recognizes the danger to Maggie and communicates it, showing situational awareness.
Requests appropriate climbing gear (ice axe, tape, crampons) to tackle a difficult overhang, demonstrating technical knowledge and preparation.
Complies with Travers' sarcastic dismissal and negotiates for tape, showing adaptability but also some frustration.
Meticulously tapes up his hands and fingers before climbing, showing careful preparation and self-care.
Takes on a dangerous free climb alone despite the risk, demonstrating determination but also a willingness to face hardship without complaint.
Does not respond to the distrust and hostility expressed by Travers and Qualen, focusing instead on the climb.
Meticulously tapes up his hands and fingers before climbing, showing preparation and attention to detail.
Moves up the wall with some ease at first, demonstrating skill and confidence in climbing.
Painfully wedges his fingers into small cracks to support his weight 3,000 feet above ground, showing physical and mental endurance and technical skill.
Keeps his hold and carefully maneuvers his hand into a crack wedge with ice despite the risk of ice chips falling, showing calculated risk-taking and focus.
Pulls himself onto the overhang exhausted but successful, demonstrating perseverance and capability under extreme conditions.
Refuses to lower the money case to Travers and Qualen, instead challenges them to come up and get it himself, risking his safety.
Hugs the wall to protect himself from the avalanche, showing focus and self-preservation under extreme danger.
Digs himself out of a crevice packed with ice and snow, gasping and coughing but alive.
Digs himself out of a narrow, ice- and snow-packed crevice with difficulty, gasping and coughing, then leans against the wall and rests, alive.
Is taking care of passengers during a dangerous storm, showing responsibility and prioritization.
Climbing the East Face, a route described as extremely difficult and only doable by a dozen people in good weather, indicating high skill and confidence despite the snowstorm.
His face is torn in pain, drenched in sweat from exertion and fear, showing vulnerability but continuing the climb.
Holds himself steady on an icy wall using improvised gear and continues to climb despite difficulty and pain.
Perseveres through extreme physical hardship and fear to continue climbing despite exhaustion and freezing conditions.
Despite exhaustion and freezing conditions, continues climbing and reaches the top of the wall.
Uses handheld crampon with extra force to secure it into the ice overhead, showing skill and awareness of the situation.
Steels himself and attempts a difficult move swinging away from the wall relying on the crampon to hold him.
Fumbles with frozen fingers and buckles while trying to remove crampon from boot, showing difficulty but ultimately succeeds.
Shows real, solid terror for the first time when facing the danger below, indicating a momentary lapse in confident composure.
Hesitates to smash the glass display case out of respect for Gordon Douglas' equipment and promises to return it.
Fumbles desperately with frozen crampon buckles but manages to remove them despite the difficulty.
Uses the freed crampon to swing and dislodge the other crampon, timing it perfectly to catch the second crampon on the same split second the first dislodges.
Quickly climbs over the ice overhang and puts crampons back on, then runs up the ice slope to the summit, showing endurance and skill.
Rushes past a tourist photo stand to focus on the important display, showing focus and purpose.
Prepares to smash the glass to get climbing equipment but hesitates out of respect, showing emotional intelligence and restraint.
Rushes toward the tree with broken branches after noticing something unusual, then frantically digs out the case from the snow, laughing as he finds it.
Scans the treeline carefully, notices broken branches indicating something unusual, and acts on it by rushing toward the tree.
Frantically searches for the case, spots a crater of snow, digs it out successfully using the tracer's blinking light.
Watches the chaos with a grin from a slightly elevated vantage point, noticing that the searchers are headed in the wrong direction.
Attempts to circle closer to help Hal and confront Travers despite danger.
Runs and dodges bullets to survive and continue pursuit, showing determination but no hostile intent.
Fumbles in his backpack and pulls out an ancient flare that looks like a can of sterno.
Uses a flare to blind Ryan and then immediately rushes to tackle him, risking his own safety to stop an enemy attack.
Throws a flare to blind Ryan, then immediately rushes to tackle him to protect himself and others.
Lunges on top of Ryan during the dangerous ice slide to control the situation and prevent further harm.
Uses Ryan's ice axe to stop their deadly slide, risking his own safety to save himself and possibly others.
Escapes down the ice after Ryan falls to his death, leaving others behind who are furious and ordering pursuit.
Smiles with memories of good times shared with friends in the cave, showing sentimental and friendly feelings.
Gratefully drinks from the hidden stash, showing appreciation and a moment of peace.
Clobbers an aggressive rat to protect himself, showing practical self-defense rather than cruelty.
Confidently drops down onto a large ledge that is obviously familiar territory for him.
Uses a penlight with low batteries but quickly switches to a lighter to proceed into the cave.
Remembers a hiding place in the cave and successfully retrieves a stash of Jack Daniels.
Calmly drinks from the stash and relaxes briefly before being startled by a rat.
Quickly kills an aggressive rat with a rock after being startled.
Properly skins and butchers a rat carcass for food, builds a fire, and manages limited resources (food and alcohol) to survive in a cave.
Puts on jacket reversed to reduce visibility, plans route carefully along rock wall using natural shelves for easier walking.
Climbs up reacting to the sound of machine gun fire but is unable to intervene.
Reacting to the sound of the machine gun fire, climbs up to intervene but finds there's nothing he can do.
Watches Evan fall and advises him to wait until out of range before pulling the parachute, showing situational awareness and calm judgment.
Turns away, unable to watch Evan's fall, grimaces and looks up with absolute hate at Travers.
Quietly threatens Travers with 'Don't worry. You will.' after hearing his mocking comment.
Hides and watches the group carefully, trying to find a way to follow without being seen.
Carefully observes the terrain using binoculars to assess a difficult climbing route (the chimney crevice) before attempting to follow the group.
Recognizes that he cannot follow the group up the bluff without being seen and adjusts his approach accordingly by moving closer to the bluff's base and scouting alternative paths.
Observes the crack carefully with binoculars and deduces that it goes all the way through the bluff, allowing a tunnel route instead of climbing the side.
Puts away the binoculars and confidently begins the difficult process of wedging himself into the crack and moving through the mountain formation.
Sweating and straining while climbing up a difficult, narrow chimney with no place to rest or pull back.
Acknowledges his mistake quietly and continues to push forward despite discomfort and fear.
Navigates a narrow, dark mountain crack with minimal clearance, uses a penlight to assess surroundings despite discomfort and fear.
Expresses nausea and admits to making a big mistake, showing self-awareness but also doubt.
Keeps pushing forward in the dark and difficult passage despite frustration and lack of visibility.
Maintains a quick climbing rhythm and uses body bracing techniques to ascend the crack.
Collides his head with a narrowing part of the passage due to not looking ahead.
Recognizes the dead end and attempts a side move despite zero visibility, showing adaptability.
Relies on a nearly dead penlight for visibility, indicating limited preparation or resources.
Curses quietly and struggles alone in a dangerous situation, showing determination but no interaction with others.
Carefully assesses the crack's width and position, attempts to find a safe opening to move through.
Loses control and falls when the crack suddenly widens, dropping the penlight and ending up trapped with no handholds or ledges.
Despite being trapped and sore, he braces himself against the walls to avoid falling further, showing endurance and presence of mind.
Carefully uses a lighter to assess the tunnel above him, noticing the widening and slant that could allow him to walk up, then prepares himself to proceed.
Perseveres steadily and carefully climbs a difficult vertical passage despite physical challenge and risk.
Carefully and steadily climbs a difficult vertical passage using a methodical technique, showing physical skill and determination.
Assesses the lack of handholds and adapts by pushing off the wall and squatting against the opposite wall to make a difficult move.
Maintains composure despite being winded and continues upward movement cautiously and skillfully.
Strains to listen to Kynette's radio communication despite difficult climbing conditions, showing concern and attentiveness.
Focuses on climbing and reaching the top, no direct interaction or hostile behavior shown.
Carefully assesses the top of the crack, noting snow conditions and light, and starts climbing with his back braced against the wall.
Hears Kynette talking and strains to listen, recognizing it might be a bad time to come up, showing situational awareness.
Kicks Kynette over the edge to protect Maggie and himself.
Yanks Maggie to her feet and grabs her hand to run, despite his own injuries.
Glowers impatiently at Maggie but continues to lead and protect her.
Throws himself over Maggie to shield her from gunfire.
Completes a risky physical maneuver by kicking Kynette over the edge, catching himself safely after a fall, showing physical skill and quick thinking.
Despite being injured and dirty, he remains focused and immediately helps Maggie to safety and leads her to run, showing resilience and leadership.
Responds quickly to gunfire by choosing a spot to jump on the snow over the crack, causing it to cave in and using the environment tactically.
Hangs from a rope anchored to a piton and rappels down into darkness, demonstrating technical climbing skills and confidence.
Throws himself over Maggie to shield her from ricocheting bullets, showing protective instincts and presence of mind under fire.
Throws himself over Maggie to shield her from gunfire.
Edges Maggie down into the crack and along a ledge, guiding her carefully.
Tells Maggie to stop despite her protests, showing concern for her safety.
Yanks the rope down hard, unintentionally causing Kynette to fall.
Throws himself over Maggie to shield her from ricocheting bullets.
Tugs gently on the rope twice to signal Kynette.
Yanks the rope down hard, unintentionally causing Kynette to fall head first into the crack.
Edges Maggie down into the narrowing crack and leads her along a ledge to avoid danger.
Recognizes his own exhaustion and stops to brace himself against the wall despite Maggie's reluctance to stop.
Expresses relief and honesty by saying 'I'm glad to see you -- but Christ, I wish you hadn't come.'
Attempts to use the radio to call for help despite difficult conditions, showing persistence and concern for rescue.
Attempts to use the radio despite difficult conditions to call for rescue.
Shows signs of exhaustion and frustration, needing to stop and catch his breath.
Checks if anyone else is on the radio, shows concern for the rescue operation.
Makes a sarcastic comment about the department going to hell after his absence.
Attempts to communicate via radio despite broken signal, actively searches for others on the radio, shows situational awareness of the rescue operation.
Expresses frustration about the department's decline after his absence, implying some self-doubt or criticism of others rather than taking full control.
Grabs Maggie as she slips and tries to protect her with his body from falling rocks.
Braces over Maggie, shielding her from the first round of falling rocks despite the danger to himself.
Grabs Maggie to protect her as they slide down the crack, shoves her against the wall, and uses his body to shield her from falling rocks.
Tries to hold on as the crack fills with rocks and dirt, jams his body against the sides to stop himself from being pushed further down.
Protects Maggie from falling rocks during cave-in.
Frantically hacks to rescue Maggie from being buried alive.
Catches Maggie as she tumbles out, brushes dirt off her face, and asks if she is all right.
Rejects Maggie's suggestion to escape upward due to danger, insists on safer route.
Unsheathes his ice axe and starts hacking up to get at Maggie, digging through falling dirt and rocks despite danger.
Carefully assesses escape routes and rejects a risky opening due to potential bombs and cave-ins, choosing a safer path.
Encourages Maggie with a smile, saying 'Come on -- we're almost out.'
Engages in a violent fight with Kynette, trying to defend himself.
Moves cautiously and skillfully along a narrow ledge, showing confidence and physical capability.
Straddles the crack and uses his feet on the opposite edge to walk faster, demonstrating resourcefulness and skill.
Is caught off guard and yanked down by Kynette, indicating a momentary lapse in vigilance.
Despite being punched and attacked with a knife, he tries to get up and fight back, showing resilience and determination.
Fights Kynette fiercely to survive, using quick thinking to trap Kynette's hand and defend himself.
Despite being in a disadvantaged fighting position and taking a brutal punch, Gabe manages to straddle the crack walls and avoid falling.
Uses quick thinking and physical skill to trap Kynette's knife hand in the rock wall by embedding the knife handle, turning the tables in the fight.
Fights back effectively with solid punches and climbs on his opponent using the trapped hand as a foothold, demonstrating resourcefulness and confidence.
Throws a punch at Kynette's stomach with no power, indicating a momentary lack of effectiveness or strength.
Shoves Maggie forward to protect her from the rockslide and urges her to move quickly.
Shoves Maggie forward and commands her to move quickly to escape the rockslide, showing quick decision-making under pressure.
Moves with Maggie out of the crevice despite the dangerous airburst and wind tunnel effect, demonstrating physical skill and presence of mind.
Hands Maggie a piton and rope, instructs her to secure it firmly.
Warns Maggie about the presence of another bomb and the urgency to move quickly.
Identifies a cave below the wall that could be useful for escape or strategy.
Uses binoculars methodically and quickly to locate the bomb and assess the situation.
Hands Maggie a piton and instructs her clearly to secure the rope.
Communicates the urgency of the situation clearly and calmly.
Expresses sorrow and apologizes to Maggie for their dire situation.
Fuses with Maggie in a tight, final embrace showing emotional connection and support.
Shows inspiration and determination by unraveling the rope to find a solution, acting to protect Maggie.
Feels completely defeated and says they will die, apologizing for the situation.
Notices the frayed end of the rope and quickly shifts from defeat to inspiration, starts unraveling the rope to use it.
Encourages Maggie to tie the old rope segments together and reassures her about their strength despite her doubts.
Dismisses Maggie's concern about the rope's age, focusing on its historical strength rather than her worry.
Offers to go after Maggie on the risky rappel, showing willingness to support and protect her.
Quickly unravels and ties together three segments of old rope from the Gordon exhibit, explaining their strength and suitability for the rescue.
Dismisses Maggie's concern about the rope's age and condition, focusing on its original strength rather than its current reliability.
Confidently offers to go after Maggie on the rappel, showing readiness and leadership in a dangerous situation.
Commands Maggie to swing towards the cave and drop, showing decisiveness and leadership under pressure.
Falls when the rope snaps but is saved by Maggie, indicating a momentary loss of control but quick recovery.
Dives into the cave with Maggie to avoid the rockslide, demonstrating situational awareness and quick reaction.

Carefully rolls Maggie over to check if she is okay after the rockslide.
Explains the dangerous situation to Maggie honestly and calmly.
Determined to act despite physical pain, showing concern for others' safety.
Lurches toward danger despite obvious physical struggle, indicating self-sacrifice.
Carefully rolls Maggie over to check if she is okay after the rockslide.
Explains the situation clearly and logically about the stolen money and the pursuers.
Plans to get to the lake first by taking a difficult route (north wall to the Bitker ladder).
Lurches towards the cave opening looking physically weak and impaired, resembling Quasimodo rather than a capable climber.
Responds to Maggie's concern with a vague plan to do 'something subtle' despite apparent physical limitations.
Initially refuses to let Maggie climb with him, insisting she climb down and find help instead.
Relents and allows Maggie to come along after she insists, showing some flexibility.
Warns Maggie that if she slows him down, he will leave her behind, showing a harsh and conditional attitude.
Accepts Maggie's help when she catches him slipping on his sore leg, indicating some trust and reliance on her.
Insists Maggie not come with him due to concern for her safety and his own physical condition, showing awareness of limitations.
Reluctantly allows Maggie to accompany him but sets clear boundaries and conditions to maintain pace and safety.
Favors one foot and slips on sore leg, indicating physical impairment but still attempts to lead the climb.
Stares immobile at the wire's edge, remembering Susan's death, showing emotional vulnerability.
Shakes his head and insists on going first to avoid hesitation, showing responsibility and sincerity.
Stares immobile at the wire's edge, momentarily frozen by memories of Susan's death.
Decides to go first across the wire despite his fear, showing resolve and self-awareness.
Drags himself across the wire despite exhaustion and fear, showing determination and resilience.
Encourages Maggie by shouting a playful challenge after completing the crossing.
Watches Maggie with a grin and admiration, showing sincere appreciation and positive regard.
Hooks his ankles over the wire and drags himself hand over hand across the abyss without a safety line, despite fatigue and near collapse, ultimately reaching the other side.
Momentarily loses grip due to exhaustion and nearly falls, but regains control by drawing on inner strength and determination.
Challenges Maggie by shouting across, showing confidence and competitive spirit after completing the crossing.
Internally acknowledges Maggie is in better shape, showing self-awareness but also a hint of insecurity.
Catches Maggie as she falls, risking his own life to save hers, holds on tightly despite pain.
Encourages Maggie to hurry across the wire, showing impatience.
Fails to notice the bolt on his side of the wire is giving way, which leads to the wire snapping and Maggie falling.
Reacting instantly with a lightning-fast motion to catch Maggie's falling hand, preventing her from falling into the chasm.
Maintains his grip on Maggie despite the extreme physical strain and danger, showing strength and skill under pressure.
Helps Maggie climb back to the ledge, ensuring her safety despite the risk to himself.
Acknowledges the danger realistically and asserts control over the situation by refusing to let Maggie continue further.
Pleading eyes and insistence that Maggie must get off the mountain alive, showing concern for her safety.
Lightly kisses Maggie but avoids making it a farewell kiss, showing sensitivity to her feelings and the situation.
Insists on ensuring Maggie's safety first, instructs her to stay out of sight and promises to meet her on the ground, showing leadership and protective instincts.
Shows emotional vulnerability by pleading with Maggie, which may indicate some internal conflict but does not diminish his competence.
Jogging and leaping across a narrow ledge with skill and renewed purpose, showing determination and focus.
Jogging and leaping across a narrow, irregular ledge with ease and skill, showing familiarity and renewed purpose.
Jumps up to grab the ladder despite the challenge, showing determination and grit.
Uproots and replants the park service sign near the top of another slope.
Rushes down behind a rock and starts gathering scattered cash to secure it.
Leaps up to grab the bottom rung of the ladder instead of falling a half mile, showing physical skill and quick decision-making.
Shoots up the ladder with ease, demonstrating physical capability and confidence.
Replants the park service sign to mark his progress, showing strategic thinking and awareness of his environment.
Rushes down to gather scattered cash quickly despite the difficult conditions, showing resourcefulness and determination.
Replants the 'Bitker Climb' sign to signal he is alive and nearby.
Startled by a frightened rabbit and leans back, relieved.

Pulls himself over the ladder, runs ahead, uproots and replants a park service sign as a signal to others, locates the shattered case, and quickly gathers the scattered cash despite difficult conditions.
Is startled by a rabbit and momentarily distracted, but quickly recovers and remains alert.
Watches Qualen's pursuit from a distance, remaining hidden and amused.
Gets caught off guard when Kristel's gun barrel hits his temple.
Warns Kristel about Qualen's intentions and tries to negotiate to avoid violence.
Quickly assesses the situation and predicts Qualen's next move, using this insight to negotiate with Kristel and de-escalate a potentially deadly confrontation.
Uses knowledge of the helicopter's capabilities to support his argument and convince Kristel to listen, demonstrating situational awareness and tactical thinking.
Engages in fast, confident dialogue under pressure, maintaining control of the interaction despite Kristel pointing a gun at him.
No direct action or involvement in the fight or situation described; remains offscreen or inactive in this excerpt.
Leads Kristel toward the storage locker, confidently indicating the location despite the tense situation.
Shows a sudden burst of enthusiasm to help Kristel by indicating the storage shed with supplies to get off the mountain.
Warns Kristel not to 'fuck up' because she still needs his help to find a route off the mountain.
Shows a sudden burst of enthusiasm and quickly moves ahead to the shed, indicating knowledge of the location and resources available.
Advises Kristel that they would make better time walking straight ahead and warns her not to 'fuck up' because she still needs him to show a route off the mountain.
Drops flat on his stomach to avoid sinking into the snowdrift and scrambles back to solid land, demonstrating quick thinking and physical skill under pressure.
Fails to recognize the danger of the snowdrift initially, as he moves toward the shed without apparent caution despite the warning sign being obscured by snow.
Uses quick thinking and physical skill to evade gunfire and survive dangerous terrain.
Despite being hit in the shoulder and sliding out of control down a slope, Gabe painfully lifts himself up and continues moving through the woods toward the lake and bridge.
Gabe cannot control his speed or direction well while sliding down the slope, barely managing to steer around obstacles.
Clings to steel supports under the bridge, enduring pain and cold to protect his friend.
Hides skillfully under the bridge, evading enemy fire despite being wounded and exposed.
Leaves a misleading blood trail ending at his empty parka to confuse the enemy.
Clings to steel supports while exposed to freezing conditions and heavy gunfire, showing physical and mental resilience.
Swings up with his ice axe to disarm Qualen, yanks down the machine gun causing Qualen to fall head first.
Engages in a brutal physical fight with Qualen despite his own injuries, showing determination and resilience.
Swings up with his ice axe, hooks it around Qualen's machine gun strap, yanks it down causing Qualen to fall head first.
Pulls himself through girders to engage Qualen in a close fight despite injury.
Holds onto Qualen's leg while falling, uses it to swing and twist, causing Qualen to lose grip and fall.
Engages in a dangerous fight on a precarious ice raft near a whirlpool, showing awareness and caution as they circle each other.
Fights fiercely against Qualen to survive, using all his strength and wits.
Struggles to survive the dangerous whirlpool and makes a risky leap to safety without hesitation.
Grins appreciatively when Hal rescues him, showing friendly and sincere response.
Quickly reacts by jumping onto another chunk of ice and braking himself with crampons to avoid falling into the whirlpool.
Leaps from one chunk of ice to another, zig-zagging and using crampons and momentum skillfully to avoid capsizing or sliding off.
Lunges for a bridge support and catches it despite being weakened, showing presence of mind and physical capability under pressure.
Struggles to his feet and looks down, wincing, indicating some physical pain or weakness but still continuing to act.
Gratefully accepts help from Hal and shares a light moment with him (grin, joking about ruined shirt).
Offers his parka to Hal despite it being damaged, showing concern for Hal's well-being.
Asks Hal if he is all right, showing care and attentiveness.
Uses humor to lighten the mood despite the dire situation (joking about the parka full of bullet holes).
Shows seriousness and concern when discussing Frank's status, indicating sincerity and emotional depth.
Communicates calmly and clearly over the radio, trying to manage the crisis and protect Maggie.
Threatens Travers if he harms Maggie, demonstrating protective loyalty and sincerity.
Expresses uncertainty and vulnerability openly ('I have no fucking idea...'), showing honesty and emotional transparency.
Successfully grabs the bridge support and attempts to climb up despite weakness and slippery conditions.
Uses the borrowed headset radio to communicate and attempts to negotiate with Travers, showing presence of mind under pressure.
Admits uncertainty about the next step with 'I have no fucking idea...'.
Tells Hal to stay over in the woods and focus on getting Maggie out safely, showing concern for others' safety.
Thanks Hal for asking him to tag along and smiles, showing appreciation and friendliness.
Bluffs by pointing an empty gun at Travers and the helicopter, using deception to protect himself and others.
Tries to force the wrong ammo clip into the gun's stock, showing a moment of frustration and lack of preparation.
Takes charge by instructing Hal to stay over and focus on getting Maggie out, showing leadership and situational awareness.
Smiles and expresses enjoyment of rescue work, indicating confidence and positive attitude toward his skills.
Bluffs by leveling an empty gun at the helicopter and holding the money over the drop, using psychological tactics to gain advantage.
Insists Maggie run to safety despite her hesitation, showing concern for her well-being.
Throws gun away after ensuring Maggie is safe, indicating restraint and non-violence.
Taunts Travers by challenging him to come and get the money, showing confidence but also a confrontational attitude.
Negotiates with Travers calmly under threat, uses psychological tactics to delay and control the situation.
Commands Maggie to run repeatedly to ensure her safety, showing situational awareness and concern.
Maintains composure and physical steadiness despite being buffeted by helicopter wind while holding the pack.
Throws the gun away but keeps the money pack suspended, balancing risk and control.
Relies on Travers' greed and curiosity to distract him, successfully preventing immediate violence.
Fails to anticipate that the money pack was already damaged and shredded, which undermines the value of the payoff.
Shoots Travers preemptively to stop him from using the gun, then makes a sarcastic remark.
Stares coldly, expecting the crash, showing no immediate concern for Travers' wellbeing.
Observes with realization as Travers regains control of the helicopter, indicating a grudging respect or acknowledgment.
Fires first at Travers decisively, hitting him in the chest before Travers can react.
Flattens himself instantly to avoid the helicopter tail swinging dangerously after Travers loses control.
Stares coldly, expecting the helicopter to crash, showing calm under pressure.
Fails to regain control of the helicopter himself, instead relying on Travers to recover control.
Fires first at Travers to stop him, then watches coldly as the helicopter spirals down, expecting a crash.
Throws himself flat into the snow to avoid being run down by the helicopter, showing presence of mind and self-preservation.
Despite being injured and exhausted, keeps trying to escape and survive rather than retaliate aggressively.
Throws himself flat into the snow to avoid being run down by the helicopter, showing quick thinking and self-preservation.
Lumbers as fast as he can toward the edge despite being injured, demonstrating determination and resilience.
Grabs the cable ladder mid-fall to stop his descent, hanging on for his life, showing courage and will to survive.
Throws himself flat into the snow to avoid being run down by the helicopter, showing presence of mind and self-preservation without reckless endangerment of others.
Despite being injured and in danger, continues to try to escape and survive rather than giving up, showing resilience but no direct interpersonal warmth.
When Travers, weakened and desperate, grabs Gabe's leg to avoid falling, Gabe struggles to support both of them, showing a moment of physical support and implicit concern.

Says 'Cheer up...' to Travers in a moment of extreme danger, which can be interpreted as an attempt to calm or encourage an enemy, indicating a degree of tolerance or good-naturedness even in conflict.
Cheer up Travers as he loses grip and falls to his death.
Clings to the ladder exhausted, too tired to climb further but accepts help when offered.
Clings to the ladder after helicopter crash despite exhaustion.
Considers giving up free climbing the remaining fifty feet due to fatigue.
Responds appropriately and efficiently by putting on the safety loop thrown by Hal despite physical pain.
Collapses into Maggie's lap after a difficult climb, showing vulnerability and trust.
Shares a deep, sincere kiss with Maggie, indicating affection and emotional openness.
Responds with 'Fuck you' when too tired to shout, showing frustration but not directed maliciously.
Puts the loop around himself and tightens it by rote despite pain, uses hand and foot holds to pull some of his weight during a difficult climb, ultimately reaches the precipice edge with help.
Collapses into Maggie's lap immediately after being hauled up, showing physical exhaustion.
Responds to Hal's sarcastic criticism with a kiss to Maggie, showing emotional confidence but not directly addressing the criticism or the situation.
